t: Luke 14
Healing of a Man on the Sabbath
One*p Sabbath, when he went to dine at the house of a ruler of the Pharisees, they were watching him carefully.
And behold, there was a man before him who had dropsy.
And Jesus responded to the lawyers and Pharisees, saying, “Is*r it*r lawful*r to*r heal*r on*r the*r Sabbath,*r or*r not?”*r
But they remained silent. Then he took him and healed him and sent him away.
And he said to them, “Which*r of*r you,*r having*r a*r son*r or*r an*r ox*r that*r has*r fallen*r into*r a*r well*r on*r a*r Sabbath*r day,*r will*r not*r immediately*r pull*r him*r out?”*r
And they could not reply to these things.
The Parable of the Wedding Feast
Now*p he told a parable to those who were invited, when he noticed how they chose the places of honor, saying to them,

“When*r you*r are*r invited*r by*r someone*r to*r a*r wedding*r feast,*r do*r not*r sit*r down*r in*r a*r place*r of*r honor,*r lest*r someone*r more*r distinguished*r than*r you*r be*r invited*r by*r him,*r

and*r he*r who*r invited*r you*r both*r will*r come*r and*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Give*r your*r place*r to*r this*r person,’*r and*r then*r you*r will*r begin*r with*r shame*r to*r take*r the*r lowest*r place.*r

But*r when*r you*r are*r invited,*r go*r and*r sit*r in*r the*r lowest*r place,*r so*r that*r when*r your*r host*r comes*r he*r may*r say*r to*r you,*r ‘Friend,*r move*r up*r higher.’*r Then*r you*r will*r be*r honored*r in*r the*r presence*r of*r all*r who*r sit*r at*r table*r with*r you.*r
For*r everyone*r who*r exalts*r himself*r will*r be*r humbled,*r and*r he*r who*r humbles*r himself*r will*r be*r exalted.”*r
The Parable of the Great Banquet

He*p said also to the man who had invited him, “When*r you*r give*r a*r dinner*r or*r a*r banquet,*r do*r not*r invite*r your*r friends*r or*r your*r brothers*r or*r your*r relatives*r or*r rich*r neighbors,*r lest*r they*r also*r invite*r you*r in*r return*r and*r you*r be*r repaid.*r
But*r when*r you*r give*r a*r feast,*r invite*r the*r poor,*r the*r crippled,*r the*r lame,*r the*r blind,*r
and*r you*r will*r be*r blessed,*r because*r they*r cannot*r repay*r you.*r For*r you*r will*r be*r repaid*r at*r the*r resurrection*r of*r the*r just.”*r
When*p one of those who reclined at table with him heard these things, he said to him, “Blessed is everyone who will eat bread in the kingdom of God!”
But he said to him, “A*r man*r once*r gave*r a*r great*r banquet*r and*r invited*r many.*r
And*r at*r the*r time*r for*r the*r banquet*r he*r sent*r his*r servant*r to*r say*r to*r those*r who*r had*r been*r invited,*r ‘Come,*r for*r everything*r is*r now*r ready.’*r

But*r they*r all*r alike*r began*r to*r make*r excuses.*r The*r first*r said*r to*r him,*r ‘I*r have*r bought*r a*r field,*r and*r I*r must*r go*r out*r and*r see*r it.*r Please*r have*r me*r excused.’*r
And*r another*r said,*r ‘I*r have*r bought*r five*r yoke*r of*r oxen,*r and*r I*r go*r to*r examine*r them.*r Please*r have*r me*r excused.’*r
And*r another*r said,*r ‘I*r have*r married*r a*r wife,*r and*r therefore*r I*r cannot*r come.’*r

So*r the*r servant*r came*r and*r reported*r these*r things*r to*r his*r master.*r Then*r the*r master*r of*r the*r house*r became*r angry*r and*r said*r to*r his*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r quickly*r to*r the*r streets*r and*r lanes*r of*r the*r city,*r and*r bring*r in*r the*r poor*r and*r crippled*r and*r blind*r and*r lame.’*r
And*r the*r servant*r said,*r ‘Sir,*r what*r you*r commanded*r has*r been*r done,*r and*r still*r there*r is*r room.’*r
And*r the*r master*r said*r to*r the*r servant,*r ‘Go*r out*r to*r the*r highways*r and*r hedges*r and*r compel*r people*r to*r come*r in,*r that*r my*r house*r may*r be*r filled.*r
For*r I*r tell*r you,*r none*r of*r those*r men*r who*r were*r invited*r shall*r taste*r my*r banquet.’”*r
The Cost of Discipleship
Now*p great crowds accompanied him, and he turned and said to them,

“If*r anyone*r comes*r to*r me*r and*r does*r not*r hate*r his*r own*r father*r and*r mother*r and*r wife*r and*r children*r and*r brothers*r and*r sisters,*r yes,*r and*r even*r his*r own*r life,*r he*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
Whoever*r does*r not*r bear*r his*r own*r cross*r and*r come*r after*r me*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
For*r which*r of*r you,*r desiring*r to*r build*r a*r tower,*r does*r not*r first*r sit*r down*r and*r count*r the*r cost,*r whether*r he*r has*r enough*r to*r complete*r it?*r
Otherwise,*r when*r he*r has*r laid*r a*r foundation*r and*r is*r not*r able*r to*r finish,*r all*r who*r see*r it*r begin*r to*r mock*r him,*r
saying,*r ‘This*r man*r began*r to*r build*r and*r was*r not*r able*r to*r finish.’*r

Or*r what*r king,*r going*r out*r to*r encounter*r another*r king*r in*r war,*r will*r not*r sit*r down*r first*r and*r deliberate*r whether*r he*r is*r able*r with*r ten*r thousand*r to*r meet*r him*r who*r comes*r against*r him*r with*r twenty*r thousand?*r
And*r if*r not,*r while*r the*r other*r is*r yet*r a*r great*r way*r off,*r he*r sends*r a*r delegation*r and*r asks*r for*r terms*r of*r peace.*r
So*r therefore,*r any*r one*r of*r you*r who*r does*r not*r renounce*r all*r that*r he*r has*r cannot*r be*r my*r disciple.*r
Salt Without Taste Is Worthless
“Salt*rp is*r good,*r but*r if*r salt*r has*r lost*r its*r taste,*r how*r shall*r its*r saltiness*r be*r restored?*r
It*r is*r of*r no*r use*r either*r for*r the*r soil*r or*r for*r the*r manure*r pile.*r It*r is*r thrown*r away.*r He*r who*r has*r ears*r to*r hear,*r let*r him*r hear.”*r
